[H1]Historical Starts[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]This is why your game won't start immediately for most Civs. Rhye's mod, above all else, was designed to mirror history. TEXT.English: Unique Powers and Historical Victories

[H1]Unique Powers and Historical Victories[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]There are no leader traits in Rhye's and Fall of Civilization. They were removed and replaced with a system of Unique Powers: each civilization has one unique ability according to its historical role. Given the different start years, each civilization have its own modifiers (which rendered leader traits useless). Their effect are summarized in the civ selection screen, at the beginning of the game, with general parameters rated 1 to 5 stars.[PARAGRAPH:2]Each Civilization can achieve a "Historical Victory" fulfilling 3 goals that differ from civ to civ and match their own historical background or just what they were trying to achieve. This way even a civilization with a weaker starting situation such as Aztecs has a chance of success. When 2 goals out of 3 are achieved, a "Triumphal Arch" is automatically built in player's capital, triggering a Golden Age.[PARAGRAPH:2]Dawn of Civilization adds historical victories for religions, which are called Unique Religious Victories (URVs). Civilizations can complete the URV of their state religion, while civilizations without access to a state religion have the opportunity to win by completing the Polytheism (when running Pantheon) or Secularism URV. The Religious Victory also differs from the Historical Victory that all goal conditions have to be fulfilled at the same time to win, and that no reward for completing two goals is available. Also, many goals are global and take the situation of all civilizations with that state religion into account.

Les effets de ces modificateurs sont rйsumйs dans l'йcran de choix de la civilisation, au dйbut de la partie, avec des paramиtres gйnйraux notйs de 1 а 5 йtoiles.[PARAGRAPH:2]Chaque civilisation peut remporter une "victoire historique" en atteignant trois objectifs, qui sont diffйrents pour chaque civilisation et dйpendent de leur histoire ou de ce qu'elles tentaient d'accomplir. De cette faзon, mкme une civilisation dйsavantagйe par sa situation de dйpart, comme les Aztиques, a une chance de gagner. Quand une civilisation a atteint deux de ses trois objectifs, un "Arc de triomphe" est construit automatiquement dans sa capitale et cela dйclenche son вge d'or.
TEXT.German: [H1]Einzigartige Mдchte und Historische Siege[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Anders als im Hauptspiel sind den Staatsoberhдuptern in Rhye's and Fall of Civilization keine Eigenschaften zugewiesen. TEXT.Italian: [H1]Poteri unici e vittorie storiche[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Non ci sono caratteristiche dei leader, in Rhye's and Fall. For most of the territory UHVs (Control the Balkans, Control Mesopotamia, etc.) you will be required to control up to 3 cities in the area. Rome is the most stringent, requiring 2 cities in Iberia, 3 cities in Gaul, 1 city in Britain, 2 cities in Africa, 4 cities in Greece and Byzantium and 2 cities in Egypt.[PARAGRAPH:2]In Dawn of Civilization, the regions that pertain to your UHV are shown in the tile tooltip when hovering over the relevant tiles.

TEXT.English: Plague

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Plague[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]The most controversial and bemoaned addition to this mod, Plague has made RFC more dynamic than even Stability. There are 5 pre-determined Plague spawns. They occur roughly at 400AD, 1300AD, 1650AD and 1850AD. There is a fifth plague that spawns only in Meso-America when Europeans first make contact. This is meant to simulate the spread of Smallpox. But fear not! There are many ways for you to control the spread and duration of the plague.[PARAGRAPH:2]Plague spreads through foreign contact and proximity to infected cities. You can limit this spread by canceling open borders, running Mercantilism and not building Embassies. The major determining factor in catching plague is your health surplus. Having far more health bonuses than unhealthiness will prevent the plague from spreading to your cities. Even if you don't reach the preventative threshold, high health will lessen the duration and severity of the plague. Granaries, Aqueducts, Harbors and Grocers are all vital to any populous empire. Even with these precautions, once a city catches plague, there is little you can do to prevent the spread to neighboring cities. Discovering Medicine will stop the plague from spreading regardless of your healthiness.

TEXT.English: Reformation

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Reformation[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]The Protestant religion is not founded like the other religions. Instead, the discovery of Printing Press by a civilization with Catholic state religion triggers the Reformation. All Catholic civilizations then have to decide if they want to convert to Protestantism and gain additional gold from the dissolution of monasteries, foregoing the benefits of the Apostolic Palace. When a civilization decides to convert, all of its cities immediately change their religion to Protestantism. Large cities also have a chance of keeping Catholicism or gaining Protestantism regardless of your decision.

Great Christian Schism

TEXT.Russian: [H1]The Great Christian Schism[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Similar to Protestantism, Orthodoxy is founded by a special event instead of only discovering a certain technology. In this case it is the Great Schism, which is triggered by building the Apostolic Palace. This represents the beginning of the tradition of the Catholic Papacy and the subsequent theological differences to the Eastern Christian churches, which manifest as the Orthodox faith in the game. That means that the civilization that builds the Apostolic Palace will not found Orthodoxy, instead another civilization will be chosen according to their historical relation to the Orthodox faith. Subsequently, other civilizations will convert to Orthodoxy depending on how far to the west the founding civilization is situated. The player will be asked whether he wants to convert, however, if he was the original founder of Orthodoxy and decides not to convert, his holy city will not receive a free shrine.

Trading Companies

[H1]Trading Companies[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]If you are either Portugal, Spain, France, England or the Netherlands, building the Trading Company triggers an event that gives you the opportunity to expand your colonial empire into South Asia. The event selects a number of target cities and gives you the choice to either attempt to acquire them by investing money or raising an army. In case of the former, the owning civ can decline your gold offer, which means the gold is lost. In case of the latter, you lose population and happiness in your capital (similar to drafting), armies appear close to the target cities and you enter war with their owners. If the target areas are empty, you get a settler there instead. AI civilizations get the same opportunity by discovering Astronomy and Gunpowder (Portugal and Spain) or Economics and Rifling (France, England and Netherlands), without building a Trading Company.[NEWLINE] The target areas of each civilization are as follows: [BOLD]Portugal:[\BOLD] three (five for the AI) cities out of Sao Salvador, Quelimane, Muscat, Goa, Cochin, Malacca and Canton [BOLD]Spain:[\BOLD] always Manila [BOLD]France:[\BOLD] one city in South India [BOLD]England:[\BOLD] three cities in India [BOLD]Netherlands:[\BOLD] three cities in Indonesia
Corporations in DoC

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Corporations in Dawn of Civilization[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Corporation headquarters and executives have been removed in Dawn of Civilization. Instead, corporations spread on their own to cities that can attract them. To be able to attract a corporation, you need to have the associated technology and control at least one of the consumed resources. The chance increases by acquiring more resources, constructing appropriate buildings or adopting the Free Market civic. The number of cities per corporation is limited, so corporations can also leave one city and move to another that fulfills its requirements better. Certain corporations also compete with each other, reducing the chance of being present in the same city.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Silk Route and Trading Company corporations behave differently from the others. They don't require the Corporation technology to spread to your cities, but are limited to certain historical regions of the map. Also, they expire after a certain date and start to leave your cities.

Respawns in DoC

[H1]Rebirths and Resurrections in Dawn of Civilization[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]There are different mechanics for collapsed civilizations to return into the game. Resurrection refers to the rules already present in vanilla RFC that allow a civilization to return if its core is controlled by independents or an unstable civilization. This effect is limited to certain periods in Dawn of Civilization, to prevent ahistorical respawns of ancient and classical civs. Also, it's not necessary to discover Nationalism to enable this mechanism, although it increases the probability of resurrections. This means that you will see resurrections occur earlier in the game. Outside of periodic checks, these resurrections can also occur when an unstable civilization collapses - if their territory includes the core of a civilization that can return, these cities will become part of this civilization instead of being independent.[PARAGRAPH:2]Dawn of Civilization also adds another mechanic that is referred to as rebirths. These are scripted and return a specific dead civ at specific dates, if certain conditions are met. Also, the faction now represents a completely new civilization with UU, UB, UP and UHV. Players can take control of these civilizations and complete their victory goals by switching to them, even if they have switched once already. Currently, this mechanic covers the rebirths of Persia as Iran, Maya as Colombia and Aztecs as Mexico.
Odds and Ends in DoC

[H1]Odds and Ends: Dawn of Civilization[\H1] - The plague can't kill units anymore - Cities of a vassalized civilization can keep control of the first ring around its cities, unless it's also the first ring of a master's city - AI civilizations become more unstable if they survive ahistorically long - The American conqueror event automatically leads to war - It's impossible to vassalize far away civilizations until the discovery of Astronomy - It's impossible to train settlers on other continents than your capital's until the discovery of Astronomy - AI Mongols get additional armies to attack Russia and the Middle East - Pagan Temples can only be built in cities without religions (this does not apply to unique buildings that replace Pagan Temples) - Religion spread to a city turns Pagan Temples into temples of the new religion - Free tech events like Liberalism or Oracle only allow to choose techs from your current or earlier eras - The Seljuks attack the Middle East in the 11th century - Buddhism is founded by building a Hindu Temple - Palace costs scale with the current game era - City tiles with resources give the best production and commerce yield that would be available by building an improvement on them - Missionary success chances depend on the civilization they attempt to proselytize, similar to the natural spread of religions - Independent civilizations can't circumnavigate or get conquerors - The spawn of the Tamil, Tibetan, Moorish, Polish and Congolese civilizations can be disabled or randomized by editing the GlobalDefinesAlt.xml file - Great artist specialists give +1 [ICON_HAPPY] - The human player isn't at war with any civilization on spawn anymore - The location of goody huts on the map is randomly determined at the beginning of the game - Revolutions still cause anarchy during Golden Ages, but the Golden Age counter will not decrease during anarchy - The range of the Blockade mission has been reduced to 2 - New set of difficulty levels: Heir, Regent, Monarch, Emperor and Paragon. Regent is the standard difficulty. Monarch and Paragon feature stronger AI opponents than their preceding levels. - You can release a civilization whose territory you control through the Domestic Advisor screen - The BUG mod has been added to the game, providing a wide array of interface improvements - The core area of certain civilizations can expand on specific conditions, such as entering a new era - Civilizations spread some of their culture on city conquest, allowing easier control of the surrounding tiles - Hurry unhappiness now scales with the amount of sacrificed population
Conditional Spawns

[H1]Conditional Spawns[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Certain civilizations in Dawn of Civilization only spawn when the right conditions are met. These civilizations are Byzantium, Italy, Thailand, Argentina and Brazil. Their requirements are listed below: [NEWLINE][BOLD]Byzantium:[\BOLD] [ICON_BULLET]Greece has to be dead [ICON_BULLET]Rome has to be alive [ICON_BULLET]If the human player controls Rome, the Byzantine spawn can be prevented by having a Solid stability [NEWLINE][BOLD]Italy:[\BOLD] [ICON_BULLET]Rome has to be dead [ICON_BULLET]There has to be at least one independent city on the Italian peninsula [NEWLINE][BOLD]Thailand:[\BOLD] [ICON_BULLET]Always spawns if the Khmer are dead [ICON_BULLET]Also spawns if the Khmer stability is Shaky or lower [ICON_BULLET]If the human player controls the Khmer, Shaky stability is sufficient to prevent the Thai spawn [NEWLINE][BOLD]Argentina:[\BOLD] [ICON_BULLET]The civilization controlling the most cities in the Argentine spawn area must not be Solid [NEWLINE][BOLD]Brazil:[\BOLD] [ICON_BULLET]The civilization controlling the most cities in the Brazilian spawn area must not be Solid [PARAGRAPH:2]Dawn of Civilization also allows to configure the spawn of the following civilizations: Tamils, Tibet, Moors, Poland and Congo. While their default setting is to appear in every game, this can be modified by editing the GlobalDefinesAlt.xml file in Assets\XML\. A value of 0 means that the civilization will not appear in the game, while a value greater than 1 means that the civilization will only appear in one out of that many games on average. For instance, setting the value for Poland to 3 means that Poland has a 1/3 chance to appear in your game. However, this setting will be ignored if you are playing as a civilization in the vicinity. For example, when playing Russia, Poland will always appear, regardless of its spawn setting.
Tile Stability Display

[H1]Tile Stability Display[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]In Dawn of Civilization, the stability effect of a specific tile is displayed in the tooltip when you hover over it on the map. The stability categories of tiles are Core (dark green), Historical (light green), Contested (yellow), Foreign (orange) and Foreign Core (red). The colors associated with the categories match those of the stability maps released for RFC.[PARAGRAPH:2]The stability category of a tile influences your expansion stability in multiple ways, depending on the circumstances. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Core Area:[\BOLD] [ICON_BULLET]Cities in your core area contribute to your core population score [ICON_BULLET]You can collapse if you're completely pushed out of your core area [ICON_BULLET]You only need 20% culture to maintain control over a tile in your core [NEWLINE][BOLD]Historical Area:[\BOLD] [ICON_BULLET]No stability penalties for controlling cities [NEWLINE][BOLD]Contested Area:[\BOLD] [ICON_BULLET]No stability penalties for controlling cities [ICON_BULLET]Risk of respawn of another civilization [ICON_BULLET]The civilization native to this area only needs 20% culture to maintain control over this tile [ICON_BULLET]It is harder to build up culture here, which can lead to stability penalties [NEWLINE][BOLD]Foreign Area:[\BOLD] [ICON_BULLET]Controlling cities here can hurt your expansion stability [NEWLINE][BOLD]Foreign Core Area:[\BOLD] [ICON_BULLET]Controlling cities here can hurt your expansion stability [ICON_BULLET]Risk of respawn of another civilization [ICON_BULLET]The civilization native to this area only needs 20% culture to maintain control over this tile [ICON_BULLET]It is harder to build up culture here, which can lead to stability penalties
Slavery

[H1]Slavery[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Dawn of Civilization aims to represent the transatlantic slave trade as part of the Columbian Exchange. To this purpose, a slave unit has been added to the game.[NEWLINE] [BOLD]Creating slave units[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Slaves cannot be trained like other units. Instead they can be created using the "enslave" button in the city screen, which takes the place of the draft button where it is available. This button is only available for civs that use the Slavery civic in cities that are situated in Sub-Saharan Africa and have a population of at least six. Like the draft action, enslaving costs one unit of population and three unhappiness, and creates a slave unit in this city. Slaves can also be acquired by defeating Impis and Pombos. If the battle took place on your territory and you are using Slavery, there is a chance that you will get a slave unit afterwards. Another alternative is purchasing slaves by trade from other civilizations, using the slave trade option of the diplomacy screen, which is explained below.[NEWLINE] [BOLD]Trading slave units[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]It is possible to acquire slaves by trade, which allows civilizations that don't have access to cities in Africa to use slaves. Trade can be conducted through the usual diplomacy interface; if the civilization you are talking to has available slave units, they appear on their side of the negotiation table and can be bought just like any other item. The same is true for the units you own. If you have adopted the Egalitarianism civic, slave trade becomes unavailable to you. Civilizations place value on slaves depending on if they have a use for them, i.e. if they have colonies in the Americas or Africa. On the other hand, native African civilizations will not buy slaves.[NEWLINE] [BOLD]Using slave units[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]The use of slaves is limited by geographical region: they can only be used in the Americas, or in Sub-Saharan Africa unless the civilization has its capital there. Slaves can be used in the following ways: [NEWLINE][BOLD]Build a slave plantation:[\BOLD] the slave can build a slave plantation on all tiles that have a resource which requires a plantation, yielding +1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] and +2 [ICON_COMMERCE] compared to a normal plantation. The slave is used in the process, similar to a work boat. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Join city as a slave specialist:[\BOLD] the slave can permanently join the city as a slave specialist, yielding 2 [ICON_PRODUCTION] and creating 1 [ICON_UNHAPPY]. The number of slaves per city is limited to half of its population.[NEWLINE] [BOLD]Freeing the slaves[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Both uses of the slave unit (plantations and specialists) can only continue as long as you are not running the Egalitarianism civic. As soon as you adopt Egalitarianism, all slave plantations on your territory will revert to normal plantations, and all slave specialists in your cities will be lost permanently. When a civilization running Egalitarianism gains control of a slave plantation, the improvement reverts to a normal plantation. Slave specialists are always removed on city conquest. If the conquering civilization is running Egalitarianism, these slaves are lost permanently. Otherwise the conqueror receives an equal amount of slave units with the opportunity of settling them elsewhere.[PARAGRAPH]The adoption of Egalitarianism by other civilizations increases the amount of unhappiness created by slaves, creating a growing incentive to adopt Egalitarianism as well to combat the unhappiness from slavery.[NEWLINE] [BOLD]The Aztecs[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]The Aztec unique power enables them to acquire slave units by winning battles; regardless of the losing unit there is a chance of acquiring a slave unit. Aztec slaves also have the additional abilities of acting as workers and can be sacrificed in their cities, as a way to temporarily increase happiness there.
Stability

[H1]Stability[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]The stability system from Rhye's and Fall has been completely replaced in Dawn of Civilization, which features a completely redesigned stability mechanic. The main principles of the new system are that no permanent stability score is stored. Instead every civilization has a stability level, ranging from the familiar Collapsing to Solid. This level can change during a stability check, which can be triggered by a number of events. During the check a stability score is calculated based on a great variety of factors. Depending on the score, the stability level can either remain constant, increase or drop. A stability drop can also cause a crisis. Crises can have different negative effects on your empire. The type of the effects depends on the category in which your stability scored the lowest, while the severity of the crisis is determined by your stability level. A crisis on Collapsing leads to a complete collapse and the elimination of a civilization. After a stability check is over, the calculated score will be discarded. This new system that does not rely on persistent scores and only calculates them during stability checks significantly improves the performance of the stability mechanic and also results in more intuitive outcomes because only the current situation in your civilization matters. [H2]Stability Levels[\H2]Stability levels represent the overall stability of your empire. Stability levels are persistent and should not be confused with the stability score which is calculated on stability checks according to the rules described below, and then discarded. There are five stability levels from best to worst: [ICON_BULLET]Solid [ICON_BULLET]Stable [ICON_BULLET]Shaky [ICON_BULLET]Unstable [ICON_BULLET]Collapsing Your stability level can change during a stability check. They also influence what happens when a stability check has a negative outcome. [H2]Stability Checks[\H2]A stability check is when your stability "matters". They don't happen periodically, but instead are triggered by a number of events: [ICON_BULLET]losing a city [ICON_BULLET]razing a city (human only) [ICON_BULLET]discovering a technology [ICON_BULLET]becoming a vassal [ICON_BULLET]acquiring a vassal (+) [ICON_BULLET]starting a war [ICON_BULLET]making peace (+) [ICON_BULLET]changing civics or state religion [ICON_BULLET]moving your capital [ICON_BULLET]building a wonder (+) [ICON_BULLET]starting a golden age (+) [ICON_BULLET]receiving a great person (+) [NEWLINE]Events marked with a (+) trigger positive stability checks. These checks cannot have negative consequences, which will be explained in more detail below. [NEWLINE]During a check, your stability score is calculated according to the rules described in the previous post. This score is compared to the stability threshold. Based on this comparison, the stability check can have three possible outcomes: [NEWLINE][BOLD]Positive:[\BOLD] The stability score exceeds the threshold by more than 10 points [BOLD]Neutral:[\BOLD] The stability score is equal to or greater than the threshold (but by not more than 10 points) [BOLD]Negative:[\BOLD] The stability score is less than the threshold [NEWLINE]The threshold itself depends on your situation. In particular, it depends on the current stability level: [ICON_BULLET]on solid: +20 [ICON_BULLET]on unstable: +10 [ICON_BULLET]on shaky: 0 [ICON_BULLET]on unstable: -10 [ICON_BULLET]on collapsing: -20 [NEWLINE]The varying threshold has the purpose of making sure that a civilization does not "fall through the levels" with a constant stability score in subsequent checks. So unless their score changes, every civilization will eventually arrive at a stability level that reflects it. [NEWLINE]The threshold is also lower later in the game to improve overall stability, and during golden ages to allow stability gains in these periods. The average stability of all other civilizations also influences the threshold to avoid a world of only unstable or only stable civs. [NEWLINE]The consequences of a stability check are as follows: [BOLD]Positive:[\BOLD] The stability level increases by one. [BOLD]Neutral:[\BOLD] Nothing happens. [BOLD]Negative:[\BOLD] The stability level decreases by one. If the previous stability level was shaky or lower, a crisis occurs. Civilizations on solid or stable cannot trigger crises. [NEWLINE]During a positive stability check (labeled with a (+) above), negative stability checks have no consequences. [NEWLINE]Human players receive an additional warning for negative outcomes of stability checks. In practice that means that they are immune against the first negative outcome of a stability check, and only subsequent negative outcomes will take effect. Instead, a warning will be displayed in the main event log. [NEWLINE]Civilizations that experience a crisis are also immune against stability checks of any kind for the next ten turns. [H2]Crises[\H2] A negative outcome of a stability check can trigger a crisis. The type of crisis depends on two factors: your [BOLD]stability level[\BOLD] and the stability category with the lowest value (the [BOLD]crisis type[\BOLD]). [NEWLINE]Negative outcomes on solid or stable don't trigger a crisis. [NEWLINE]A crisis on collapsing is also called a [BOLD]terminal crisis[\BOLD] and always leads to a complete collapse of the civilization, regardless of crisis type. AI civilizations are immune to collapses triggered by stability checks from declarations of war by the human player. [NEWLINE] Crises on shaky are [BOLD]moderate crises[\BOLD], while crises on unstable are [BOLD]severe crises[\BOLD]. Their effects depend on the crisis type, i.e. there are: [ICON_BULLET]territorial crises (expansion) [ICON_BULLET]economic crises (economy) [ICON_BULLET]domestic crises (domestic) [ICON_BULLET]diplomatic crises (foreign) [ICON_BULLET]military crises (military) [NEWLINE][BOLD]Territorial Crisis:[\BOLD] Moderate: a single city secedes from your empire. It is chosen according to your stability map, so if available it will be a city on ahistorical territory. Severe: "Collapse to core": if more than half of all non-core cities are ahistorical, all ahistorical cities will secede. Otherwise, all non-core cities will secede. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Economic Crisis:[\BOLD] Moderate: You lose gold equivalent to 50% of your research progress (sum of all techs which you have begun to research). If you do not have enough gold on treasury, the beakers invested in the techs will be subtracted directly. Severe: You lose gold equivalent to 100% of your research progress (see above). All your cottages downgrade one level. You lose all GP points in all cities. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Domestic Crisis:[\BOLD] Moderate: All unhappy cities will go into two turns of unrest. Severe: Two turns of anarchy. All unhappy cities secede. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Diplomatic Crisis[\BOLD] Moderate: Your relations with 2 civilizations will deteriorate. Severe: Your relations with 5 civilizations will deteriorate. All your vassals are set free. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Military Crisis[\BOLD] Moderate: The defense value of all cities with enemy claim is reduced to 0. Severe: Two turns of unrest in all cities with enemy claim. You cannot move all military units for one turn.
Stability Influence Factors

[H1]Stability Influence Factors[\H1] [NEWLINE][BOLD]EXPANSION[\BOLD] [NEWLINE][BOLD]Overextension[\BOLD] Overextension is the main factor of expansion stability. It depends on two scores: [ICON_BULLET]core population score [ICON_BULLET]periphery population score [NEWLINE]Without taking modifiers into account, they are just the population in your core and the population outside of your core, respectively. As long as your periphery population score is below your core population score, everything is fine. Once the periphery score exceeds 100% of the core population score, you will receive an expansion stability penalty according to a formula which I will explain later. The scores are affected by a number of modifiers and therefore aren't only based on city population. [NEWLINE]The [BOLD]core population score[\BOLD] is multiplied by your current era plus one. Since the modifier is era-based, your ability to support a large periphery grows during the game. [NEWLINE]The [BOLD]periphery population score[\BOLD] for every city is based on many different factors. Since a lower periphery score is better for stability, negative modifiers are desired. +2 if the city is not on historical territory (so it makes sense to mainly control historical tiles) +1 if you are not the original owner of this city (unless you are running Totalitarianism or Warrior Code, or the city is under your control for more than 25 turns) +1 if you have less than 50% culture in this city +1 if you have less than 20% culture in this city (those two penalties are cumulative, for a total of +2 if you are below 20%. Culture counts double within their civilization's own cores. Persia is immune to culture-based penalties due to their UP) +2 when running City States (this civic is only meant for small civilizations) +1 if it is a historical overseas city an you are running Totalitarianism (to discourage Totalitarianism for maintaining colonial empires) -1 if the city has a Courthouse -1 if the city has a Jail -1 if it is an overseas city and you are running Mercantilism -1 if it is an overseas city and you are Portugal (their UP) [NEWLINE]The expansion penalty can be at most -25, and grows faster right after the periphery score exceeds the core score than later on. This allows a diminishing yet growing effect of expansion stability that allows playing Domination games without making expansion stability irrelevant in more historical games. [NEWLINE]Between stability checks, the overextension penalty can only increase by at most 5 negative points. For instance, if you had a penalty of 0 in the last check and the calculation results in -10, you will still only get a penalty of -5 until the next check. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Razing[\BOLD] Razing cities is the other contributing factor to expansion stability. The score here is very straightforward. You get a -10 stability penalty for every city you have razed. This penalty decays by 2 points every 5 turns. This penalty is global, that means if you accrue -20 raze stability from razing two cities, it still decays by 2 points every 5 turns, instead of by 4. The exception to this rule are smaller cities. If the city has a population of less than 5, the penalty is -2 * [city population] instead. This exception does not apply to another civilizations capital, which always gives a -10 penalty when razed. [NEWLINE][BOLD]ECONOMY[\BOLD] [NEWLINE][BOLD]Economic Growth[\BOLD] The economic growth score is updated every third turn, in which the total amount of commerce produced is compared to the amount from three turns earlier. Has it grown by more than 5%, the score increases, has it shrunk by more than 5%, it decreases. Otherwise the score slowly moves towards 0 again. At every stability check the score is directly applied to the economy stability. Some of your civics influence your economic growth stability: [ICON_BULLET]you receive extra points during economic growth when running Free Market [ICON_BULLET]you receive no penalties during economic stagnation when running Environmentalism [ICON_BULLET]you receive less penalties during economic decline when running Public Welfare [NEWLINE][BOLD]Trade[\BOLD] Your cities have trade routes to other cities generating commerce (exports). Other cities have trade routes to your cities also generating commerce (imports). For all civilizations, their total trade volume is calculated, which usually is the sum of exports and imports, but for Mercantilist civs it is twice their export volume instead. The trade volume is divided by your number of cities, then subtracted a modifier that increases with your era. Effectively, you can achieve a positive score by increasing the trade yield in your cities and securing trade routes with foreign cities. The trade stability is capped at +10 and -10 respectively. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Economic Systems[\BOLD] Civilizations running Mercantilism receive a -2 penalty for having open borders with a civilization with a higher commerce output. Civilizations running Central Planning receive a -2 penalty for having open borders with a civilization that runs Free Market. [NEWLINE][BOLD]DOMESTIC[\BOLD] [NEWLINE][BOLD]Happiness[\BOLD] Happiness stability works similar to economic growth stability in that it is accumulating every third turn depending on the situation of your civilization. To that end, the happy and unhappy cities in a civilization are counted based on the following criteria: [NEWLINE][BOLD]Happy city:[\BOLD] currently celebrates the "We Love the King" day OR its happiness exceeds its unhappiness by at least a quarter of your empire's average city size and it has at least the average city size of your empire [BOLD]Unhappy city:[\BOLD] the city has more unhappiness than happiness OR the extra unhappiness (from all factors except population) exceeds a fifth of the city's population [NEWLINE]Note that it is possible for a city to not fulfill either of these criteria, in which case it doesn't count at all for the purposes of happiness stability. A city can also both fulfill the criteria for being happy and unhappy, in which case it counts as happy. Your happiness stability grows every third turn if you have more happy than unhappy cities, and declines if you have more unhappy than happy cities. This factor cannot exceed -10 or 10, respectively. If the amount of happy and unhappy cities is exactly the same, the value slowly approaches 0 again. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Religion[\BOLD] For religions, two or three percentages are calculated: [ICON_BULLET]the percentage of cities that have your state religion (believer ratio) [ICON_BULLET]the percentage of cities that have at least one non-state religion (heathen ratio) [ICON_BULLET]if you are running Theocracy, the percentage of cities that have ONLY your state religion [NEWLINE]Some non-state religions are ignored for the purposes of the second and third ratios ("tolerance"). [ICON_BULLET]civs with Secularism tolerate all non-state religions [ICON_BULLET]Mughals tolerate all non-state religions because of their UP [ICON_BULLET]Hinduism and Buddhism tolerate each other [ICON_BULLET]Confucianism and Taoism tolerate each other [NEWLINE][BOLD]Heathen ratio:[\BOLD] You incur neither penalties nor bonuses if your ratio is 30%. Otherwise, you receive -1 stability for every 10% over 30% and +1 stability for every 10% below 30%. [BOLD]Believer ratio:[\BOLD] You incur neither penalties nor bonuses if your ratio is 75%. Otherwise, you receive -1 stability for every 5% below 75% (up to a maximum of -10) and +1 stability for every 5% over 75%. [BOLD]Theocracy bonus:[\BOLD] if you are running Theocracy, you also receive +1 stability for every 20% of your cities that only have your state religion. [NEWLINE]Note that while the other factors require you to have a state religion, the religion stability from the heathen ratio also applies when you don't have a state religion. Diplomatic Institutions

[H1]Diplomatic Institutions[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]The [BOLD]Apostolic Palace[\BOLD] and [BOLD]United Nations[\BOLD] have seen some changes in Dawn of Civilizations. Several rules have been modified and certain resolutions were to increase their impact and make them more interesting to interact with. General changes: [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Instead of being directly proportional to population, the number of votes of a civilization are now proportional to the square root of its population. This reduces the influence of large civilizations and makes cooperation with smaller civilizations more important. [ICON_BULLET]Defying resolutions now follows different rules for the two institutions. [ICON_BULLET]When a civilization attempts to win a diplomatic victory, its own votes and the votes of its vassals are disregarded. Instead it needs to win a majority among the remaining votes. This way, the diplomatic victory truly requires diplomacy, and cannot be achieved by military subjugation. [H2]Apostolic Palace[\H2] [ICON_BULLET]Only civilizations with Catholic state religions are members of the Apostolic Palace and allowed to vote. [ICON_BULLET]Resolutions that affect all members don't fail only because a member defies it. [ICON_BULLET]Instead, civilizations defying resolutions are not affected by them. The usual penalties (loss of membership, unhappiness, diplomatic penalties) still apply. [ICON_BULLET]Renamed the "Declare War" resolutions to "Crusade". Valid targets are non-members who are at war with a member (defensive crusade) and non-members who control the Catholic holy city or shrine (offensive crusade). [ICON_BULLET]New "Collect Tithe" resolution: all members pay 10% of their treasury of which the Pope receives half. [ICON_BULLET]New "Send Inquisition" resolution: the Pope receives additional espionage against the target civilization. [ICON_BULLET]New "Excommunication" resolution: the target loses membership and receives unhappiness as if they had defied a resolution. [H2]United Nations[\H2] [ICON_BULLET]Security Council: only the four civilizations with the highest military power are allowed to defy resolutions. [ICON_BULLET]New "Decolonize City" resolution: Cities on other continents can be forced to be liberated to independents. [ICON_BULLET]New "Release Civilization" resolution: If a civilization can respawn, another civilization controlling their territory can be forced to release it.
Congresses

[H1]Congresses[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Congresses in Rhye's and Fall represent the phenomenon of informal institutionalization of international politics that began during the 19th century. This includes the idea of the balance of power which manifested itself in the Congress of Vienna and the Concert of Europe, but also international conferences on territorial claims such as the Berlin Congress. They also represent other diplomatic exchanges of territory like the Louisiana Purchase.[PARAGRAPH:2]Congresses take place as soon as the first civilization discovers Nationalism and regularly occur every 15 turns. The ten most powerful civilizations of the world will be invited, and each of them can either claim a city or request to found a colony on unsettled territory. If the majority of civilizations agrees, the request is granted and the city will change hands or a settler will be created on the demanded empty spot. While the human player can decide on claims by voting YES, NO or ABSTAIN, the AI will make its own decisions based on a variety of factors. These include the legitimacy of the claim (e.g. if the claimed city is historical for the civilization or if it already has culture there), the relationship to the demanding and controlling civilizations, including their own interest in the city.[PARAGRAPH:2]If a player claim was considered legitimate by an AI, but not granted because of insufficient relations, or if a player city has been granted to another civilization by the AI, the player can choose a number of options to influence the vote of AI civilizations in their favor. This can happen either through bribery (offering gold) or manipulation (expending espionage points). The player can spend varying amounts of both resources depending on how much they consider influencing their votes necessary. Another way to influence the AI is by agreeing to their own claims in the same congress - or at least avoiding to vote against them![PARAGRAPH:2]If all attempts fail and the congress still gives away one of your cities, you still have the opportunity to refuse handing it over. But be careful, this may cause some of the civilizations that agreed to the request to go to war over your contempt for their decision! The more votes were in favor of reassigning the city, the likelier an individual civilization is to go to war.[PARAGRAPH:2]Congresses are disrupted by global wars, under which different rules apply. A global war takes place when at least half the military power of the world is at war with each other. During these times, no congresses occur because the world is settling its differences on the battlefield instead of the negotiation table. However, when such a global war ends (by the main belligerents agreeing to peace), peace is enforced on all belligerents and a new congress is called to restore order after the war. Such a congress differs from normal congresses in that only belligerents are invited, that only civilizations on the winning side are allowed to make demands, and that it is impossible to request colonizing free territory. Civilizations that have lost the war still can vote on all claims, however. Congresses completely come to an end when the United Nations are built because their formalized approach to multilateral diplomacy makes congresses obsolete. [NEWLINE]If you are familiar with Congresses from Rhye's and Fall, you will notice multiple significant changes and improvements over the previous system, some of which have already been mentioned: [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]In addition to periodic congresses, congresses can also occur after global wars [ICON_BULLET]Participants can also request to settle free territory [ICON_BULLET]A streamlined interaction process so that the entire congress can be resolved in one turn [ICON_BULLET]Significant improvements in computation times [ICON_BULLET]When voting on a claim, the camera centers on the plot or city in question [ICON_BULLET]The option to influence a civilization's decision is only offered when there is actually a chance of success [ICON_BULLET]Attempts to influence a decision are now specific to a certain claim and can be used both to achieve agreement to an own claim and disagreement with a claim on your own cities [ICON_BULLET]There is no limit on how many civilizations can be attempted to be influenced during the same Congress [ICON_BULLET]In addition to bribery by offering gold, votes can also be manipulated by expending espionage [ICON_BULLET]More sophisticated AI decisionmaking: it now takes the legitimacy of the claim, its relations to the claimant and owner, and its own interest in the city into account [ICON_BULLET]More global AI decisionmaking: your own voting behavior influences how the AI treats your claims and the claims against you, global opinion influences how likely AIs are to go to war over a refused claim [ICON_BULLET]No more multiple assignments during the same Congress: if more than one civilization have successfully claimed the same city, it goes to the civilization that received the most votes in favor
